awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an Energy-Filtering, Direct Electron Detector for Advanced Soft and Hard Materials Research with In Situ Transmission Electron Microscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
This project provides a novel detection system for an electron microscope enabling unprecedented advances in imaging and spectroscopy to resolve fundamental scientific issues in biology, energy, environmental sciences and quantum information technologies. Such advances make enormous contributions toward understanding how atoms arrange and bond in materials in both their native and working states, thereby providing completely new insights that enhances understanding and increases our ability to manipulate and control chemical, material, and biological systems. The researchers have a strong commitment to diversity and inclusion in their research, outreach, and educational activities. This novel system is accessible to researchers outside ASU and thus give significant regional impact. The wonders of materials/biological structures and functionalities obtained from this system are communicated to rural and underprivileged K-12 communities through the well-developed programs in the Fulton Schools of Engineering and the College of Liberal Arts and Science. In addition, the researchers have developed programs for student leadership initiatives and female participation related to materials and microscopy at the Microscopy Society of America, as well as in the annual Electron Microscopy Winter School hosted at ASU. 

This system is a novel, high-sensitivity, energy-filtering, direct electron detector to install on an aberration-corrected in situ FEI Titan environmental transmission electron microscope. This new system provides unprecedented sensitivity for imaging and spectroscopy, and mitigates the long-standing electron beam induced damage problems that has plagued analysis of many materials and biological systems. This project enables four key research areas that have been identified by their scientific importance and impact to the broader communities: (1) Understanding the structure of soft/biological materials and their interfaces with hard materials. (2) Observing functionally important defects and structural heterogeneities in zeolites and metal-organic frameworks at atomic resolution. (3) In situ, real-time, atomic-level identification and dynamic characterization of active sites in catalysts. (4) Developing single-photon sources (SPSs) from point defects in solid-state materials is critical for many scalable quantum technologies

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Materials play a key role in all aspects of society and understanding their structures and properties is an ongoing intellectual challenge.  Elucidating the relationship between the properties of materials (e.g. their color, electrical properties, mechanical strength, etc..) and the structure of the materials will enable us to build new and better materials. At the most fundamental level, materials are built from atoms and the atoms are often arranged in periodic patterns called crystals. Interestingly, many of the important properties of the materials are associated with imperfections in the pattern, so-called crystal defects. The ability to detect and characterize these defects is essential to develop a deep understanding of materials properties.  The atoms in a material can be directly visualized using advanced electron microscopes. In the electron microscope, we magnify the image of the sample over one million times so that we can see the atoms (which are very tiny, with diameters of only 10-10 m).  The eyes of an electron microscope are called electron detectors, and they are a critical part of the technology. In some ways, the electron microscope is only as good as the detectors.

In recent years, an entirely new generation of electron detectors has been developed, called direct electron detectors.  These detectors are much more sensitive than the previous generation and can run at speeds in excess of 1000 frames per second, enabling us to monitor the dynamics of the atoms in the material. The information about the material can be obtained from many different signals with an electron microscope which include imaging, spectroscopy and diffraction.  The direct electron detectors are able to detect all these signals which enable us to build up a detailed picture not only about how the atoms are arranged in the material but also how the atoms are connected and bonded to each other. 

Two detectors were purchased for two different electron microscopes. One of the detectors, a Gatan K3 system, was installed in an FEI Environmental transmission electron microscope. This microscope has the ability to expose samples to different stimuli (heat, gas, light, etc?) so the new detector enables us to directly observe how the atoms in the material respond to these stimuli.  A second detector, a Dectris ELA, was installed on a NION scanning transmission electron microscope.  This microscope excels for spectral analysis from tiny volume and allows us to prove vibrational, excitonic, plasmonic and photonic responses in materials.
